definition: Zhuangzi (369-286 BC), Daoist author
variant of 莊|庄[zhuang1]
farmstead/village/manor/place of business/banker (in a gambling game)/grave or solemn/holdings of a landlord (in imperial China)
surname Zhuang
(noun suffix)

son/child/seed/egg/small thing/1st earthly branch: 11 p.m.-1 a.m., midnight, 11th solar month (7th December to 5th January), year of the Rat/Viscount, fourth of five orders of nobility 五等爵位[wu3 deng3 jue2 wei4]/ancient Chinese compass point: 0° (north)

sentences.english: Chapter Five studies the allegorical expression in illustrate Zhuangzi Inner Pieces.
sentences.chinese: 第五章分析了《庄子》内篇寓言型的表达方式。

sentences.english: Chuang Tsu stresses on the natural principle of 'Tao' and the regulative character of the beauty.
sentences.chinese: 庄子强调了“道”的自然性原则和美的合规律的特点。

sentences.english: The philosophy of Zhuangzi is more objective than that people usually thought of.
sentences.chinese: 庄子哲学要比人们通常所认为的现实得多。

sentences.english: Chuang-tzu's theory of man's nature, simplisy, is the base of his theory of cultivating virtues.
sentences.chinese: 庄子的人性素朴论是其德行修养观的基石。

sentences.english: The interrogative pronoun is plentiful in Zhangzi.
sentences.chinese: 《庄子》中疑问代词使用十分丰富。

sentences.english: Huizi felt that Chuang Tzu did it too far.
sentences.chinese: 惠子觉得庄子这样的行为实在是太过分了。

sentences.english: Zhuangzi is an ancient book that illustrated philosophical principles through parabolical images.
sentences.chinese: 《庄子》之书，以寓言地步来证明哲学道理。

sentences.english: Bian Zhuangzi felt the waiter had a good point, so he stood to the side and watched the fight unfold.
sentences.chinese: 卞庄子觉得很有道理，就在一旁观察局势的发展。

sentences.english: Because Buddha and Jesus emphasise effort and Chuang Tzu emphasises effortlessness.
sentences.chinese: 因为佛陀与耶稣主张有为，而庄子强调的是无为。

sentences.english: The Taoism of Zhuangzi is a kind of beauty implied in all things.
sentences.chinese: 庄子之道，就是一种蕴涵在天地万物当中的美。

sentences.english: But serious if the say thing that Chuang Tzu.
sentences.chinese: 而是正经八百的再说这庄子事儿。

sentences.english: Chuang Tzu in swords clothes strode to the court.
sentences.chinese: 庄子穿着剑服阔步地来到殿前。

sentences.english: The academic circle all agree that Zhuangzi's social perspectives were retrogressive, and should be criticized.
sentences.chinese: 学界一致认为庄子的社会观是倒退的，应受到批判。

sentences.english: Zhuangzi holds that the secret of apprehending Tao is subtraction of life, namely "emptiness".
sentences.chinese: 庄子认为，悟道真正的奥秘在于“虚”。

sentences.english: It is also the first English version that claims to emphasize Chuang-tzu's philosophy.
sentences.chinese: 也是第一部强调庄子哲学的译本。

sentences.english: Chuang-tzu islands is located in rural Chuang-tzu Pro Pu Village North five hundred meters.
sentences.chinese: 庄子钓鱼台位于临濮乡庄子庙村北五百米左右。

definition: Mencius (c. 372-c. 289 BC), Confucian philosopher second only to Confucius/book of the same name, one of the classics of Confucianism
Han Feizi, book of Legalist Philosophy authored by Han Fei 韓非|韩非[Han2 Fei1] during the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)
Xun Zi or Hsun Tzu (c. 310-237 BC), Confucian philosopher and author of On learning 勸學|劝学
Confucius (551-479 BC), Chinese thinker and social philosopher, also known as 孔夫子[Kong3 fu1 zi3]
Confucius
Laozi and Zhuangzi (or Lao-tze and Chuang-tze), the founders of Daoism
another name for Laozi 老子[Lao3 zi3]
The Analects of Confucius 孔子[Kong3 zi3]
Hui Shi, also known as Hui-zi 惠子[Hui4 zi5](c. 370-310 BC), politician and philosopher of the School of Logicians 名家 [Ming2 jia1] during the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)
Mencius 孟子 (c. 372-c. 289), Confucian philosopher
Master/(old form of address for teachers, scholars)/pedant
Confucian school, founded by Confucius 孔子[Kong3 zi3] (551-479 BC) and Mencius 孟子[Meng4 zi3] (c. 372-c. 289 BC)
Lie Zi, Daoist author, said to be early Warring States period 戰國|战国/Daoist text in eight chapters, said to be by Lie Zi, probably compiled during WeiJin times 魏晉|魏晋 (3rd century AD)
Wei Liaozi, one of the Seven Military Classics of ancient China 武經七書|武经七书[Wu3 jing1 Qi1 shu1], possibly written by Wei Liao 尉繚|尉缭[Wei4 Liao2] during the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)
Yang Zhu (c. 440-360 BC), Chinese philosopher advocating ethical egoism
the Book of Dao by Laozi or Lao-Tze, the sacred text of Daoism
